newsitem.title: FRANCE: France's Gle des Eaux aims to be telecoms giant.
newsitem.headline: France's Gle des Eaux aims to be telecoms giant.

text.p: French diversified utility Generale des Eaux said on Wednesday it aimed to take advantage of deregulation to become the country's second largest telecommunications operator after state-owned France Telecom.
"The competition will be very useful for mobile telephone users and tomorrow for the entire range of telephone services," company chairman Jean-Marie Messier told a news conference.
Messier's comments came as he announced the creation of a new holding company to group the utility's telecommunications activities, to be known as Cegetel.
The holding company is being set up ahead of legislation due to come into effect on January 1, 1998, deregulating the French telecommunications market.
Under the act, telephone users will be able to choose their suppliers for both local and long distance calls.

"This date (January 1, 1998) will mark an opening of the telecommunications market without precedent on a world scale...in the fact that in one step, 90 percent of the market that today is inaccessible will open up to competition," he said.

Generale des Eaux, which already has a wide portfolio of mobile telephone licences, said it would invest four billion francs ($786.3 million) annually in telecommunications between 1997 and 1999 of which 2.3 billion francs would be earmarked for mobile telephones.
The utility valued the telecommunications market in 1995 at 117 billion francs, of which six billion represented the market for mobile telephones.
It forecast the telecoms market would grow to 187 billion francs by 2003 of which 55 billion would be in mobile phones.
Messier, who will serve as chairman of the new holding, forecast Cegetel would generate a net profit as of 1999.
Its flagship mobile telecommunications unit, Societe Francaise de Radiotelephone (SFR), would become profitable in 1998 after achieving breakeven in 1997, he said.

Messier said competition in the telecommunications sector would allow the group to create "during the coming years undoubtedly 10,000 direct jobs, without counting the indirect jobs which could represent two or three times that amount."
Generale des Eaux will hold "strong, majority control" of Cegetel reflecting "the group's attachment to its independence," Messier said.
But Cegetel's capital will also be open to Generale des Eaux's "strategic partners" which have already expressed interest, Messier said.

These partners are notably Southwestern Bell of the U.S. and Britain's Vodafone which hold stakes in Generale des Eaux's telecommunications unit Cofira which will come under Cegetel's umbrella. ($1=5.087 French Franc)
